e4: I recommend changing to the new policy because transparency and accuracy in reporting earnings are fundamental principles of good governance. Although some investors may initially react negatively, it is essential to prioritize honesty and precision over potential short-term market reactions. The current policy's intentional bias may be seen as manipulative or deceitful, which can damage the company's reputation and relationships with stakeholders in the long run.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should prioritize transparency, accuracy, and honesty. It should provide stakeholders with clear, unbiased, and complete information to make informed decisions. In the context of financial reporting, this means avoiding intentional biases or manipulations that can mislead investors. Considerations such as market volatility, investor sophistication, and regulatory compliance are also important. A policy that balances these factors while maintaining integrity and transparency would be considered ethical. This includes being proactive in communicating changes to policies and ensuring that all stakeholders have access to the same information.
e6: Yes, I would ask follow-up questions. How do you plan to communicate the change in policy to investors and stakeholders to minimize potential negative reactions? What metrics or benchmarks will be used to assess the impact of the new policy on investor perceptions and market performance? Are there any plans for additional transparency initiatives or investor education programs to support the transition to unbiased reporting?
